(3) Code-Like Forms. Considering that natural language descriptions and other 1-D sequences are inherently inadequate for directly representing the 2-D structure of graph data, and given the robust code comprehension capabilities of LMs, many researchers [49] explore using code-like formats to represent graph structures. For example, Guo et al. [49] examine the use of Graph Modeling
Language (GML) [56] and Graph Markup Language (GraphML) [141] for representing graphs.
These standardized languages are specifically designed for graph data, providing comprehensive descriptions that encompass nodes, edges, and their interrelationships.
